summary: A character reference letter written to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail request. The author, who has known Maxwell since her youth, attests to her good character, work ethic, and generosity, expresses shock at her arrest, asserts her innocence, and argues she would not flee if granted bail.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the character reference letter. The author describes her as a lovely, energetic, capable, warm, loving, and generous person who is innocent of the charges and would not flee if granted bail.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case in the Southern District of New York, to whom this character reference letter is addressed.

connections.description: The author has known Ghislaine Maxwell since she was young, has remained close with her, and has sent their own daughter to spend time with her.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The author references the arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell, expressing utter shock at it.

events.title: Scheduled Court Date
events.description: The author states Ghislaine Maxwell is determined to fight the charges in court in July 2021.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a character reference letter submitted to the court in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's 2020 bail request.
The author, who has known Maxwell since her youth, strongly asserts her innocence and describes her as incapable of the alleged behavior.
The author states that many friends and their children have visited and stayed with Ghislaine Maxwell over the years, and that the author sent their own daughter to spend time with her.
The letter argues Maxwell would not flee if granted bail because she is determined to clear her name at her scheduled July 2021 trial.
The document reveals a planned trial date of July 2021 for Ghislaine Maxwell's case.
